H0.text: Meter per liter is the unit the student is most likely using to describe the speed of the ball rolling down the ramp.

H1.text: Seconds per gram is the unit of measurement the student is most likely using to describe the speed of the ball rolling down the ramp.

H2.text: Milligrams per liter is the unit of measurement that a student is most likely using to describe the speed of a ball rolling down a ramp.

H3.text: Centimeters per second is the unit most likely used by the student measuring the speed of a ball rolling down a ramp.

A4.text: The SI unit of speed is the metre per second (m/s).

A5.text: The most common unit of speed in everyday usage is the kilometre per hour (km/h) or, in the US and the UK, miles per hour (mph).

A6.text: The metre per second is the unit of both speed (a scalar quantity) and velocity (a vector quantity, which has direction and magnitude) in the International System of Units (SI)

A7.text: The metre per second became the official SI derived unit for both speed and velocity with the establishment of the International System of Units (SI) in 1960 by the General Conference on Weights and Measures (CGPM)

A9.text: speed has the derived unit metre per second.

A10.text: The centimetre–gram–second system (CGS) was the first coherent metric system, having been developed in the 1860 เดือนs and promoted by James Clerk Maxwell and Lord Kelvin.
